comments.author: Mcginn202

comments.text:
SPOILER WARNING





I prefer how Joffrey met his end in the series proper. It wasn't "just" in 
that a Stark didn't (directly or knowingly) kill him, but his humiliating 
death was still appropriate considering how he had been casually 
humiliating tons of people minutes before (Ser Dontos, the performing 
dwarves, Tyrion). It was as if fate was biding its time to kill him, calmly 
keeping a track of Joffrey's bad karma, but went "fuck it" after Joffrey 
went Maximum Overdouche at the wedding.﻿
comments.author: BullockDS

comments.text:
If the Starks wanted to win they should have allied with Stannis from the 
start, Robb could have immediately married his daughter (in the books he 
has one) thus making him Stannis' heir. Bran (and Rickon) would have 
inherited Winterfell and could have then been married off to the Frey's. 
This would have made an alliance that would have knocked Tywin Lannister 
out of the game. Arya would have reached her family much sooner and could 
have been married to Theon Greyjoy, bringing the Ironborn in their side. 
Arya is the only women who could have kept the Ironborn in line anyway. 
Renly would have taken King's landing but lost too many men to survive 
against the alliance.

 The only real flaw here is Sansa would have died at Cercei's hand rather 
than be freed...﻿

comments.author: Salem Andrada

comments.text:
okay, this is me apologising for my behaviour. I am actually quite taken 
back about your arguments and while trying to present my opinion, I ended 
up sounding like a massive douche and pissing you guys off more.
I am quite new to GoT, I have recently finished the second book. However, 
Ned grew on me throughout the first book and I felt quite shocked when he 
was executed, and even more so at Sansa when she told Cercei what was going 
to on. Sansa, to me, was a girl I absolutely hated in the second book, but 
now she has seen Joffrey in a new light and actually started acting grown 
up she too has slightly grown on me.
I still believe Jon and Arya to be my favourites, despite what others may 
say.
[GOOD DAY.]
comments.author: franki saurus

comments.text: +franki saurus lol sorry, didn't mean to jump on you
comments.author: Syedaxox

comments.text: shit okay, sorry sorry. God, so many people...
comments.author: franki saurus

comments.text:
+franki saurus First of all, your argument that Sansa is somehow to blame 
for Ned's death is completely lacking in factual evidence.  Say you don't 
like her because she seems selfish or bratty to you, but don't blame her 
for things that the actual text does not support.  Secondly, I can't 
believe you actually  say she "killed the father to one of your favorite 
characters", as if Lord Eddard Stark was not SANSA'S father, too.   What -- 
is she not good enough to be a precious Stark?  Not "tough" enough or 
"wolf" enough?  Do you honestly think Ned did not love her as much as he 
loved all of his other children?
comments.author: Tommy 417

comments.text:
+franki saurus its cool if you dislike a character, that is your opinion. 
but when people start pinning the blame on sansa for ned's death (among 
other things), I don't think it's justified and it still means something to 
pin blame and insult a young girl for such things even if they're 
fictional. (I agree that she's spoiled and stupid, although I still don't 
feel like I can pin responsibility on her).
comments.author: Syedaxox

comments.text:
Yeah honey whatevs. No one said you have to like her. I said hate, which is 
different. And I am talking about people who stupidly and ridiculously make 
all sorts of bullshit claims about her (oh, and don't try to imply I care 
too much about a fictional character when you're still trying to push this 
argument after several months when no one was even addressing you 
directly). I was talking about something you are just fundamentally wrong 
about and your laughable lack of logic that dictates that the grown man who 
revealed lethal information and didn't cover his bases despite his superior 
knowledge of the situation he was in is less responsible for his death than 
his eleven year old daughter who didn't know what the Hell was going on. I 
didn't say you mentioned sewing or fighting. But I am pretty sure you've 
got some serious internal misogyny issues. But keep enjoying the belief 
that everything in the world is about you and you alone.

But I am not surprised that Arya is one of your favorite characters. 
SHOCKING (and no, that is not a knock against Arya or Arya fans because I 
am one of them, it's a knock against Arya fans like you)
comments.author: Wendy Weissman

comments.text:
Didn't mention anything about who sows what and who fights who, also didn't 
call her horrible or anything of the sort; instead I used words such as 
'stupid' and 'spoilt' which clearly represent the image I have of her in my 
mind.
Still doesn't change the fact that I dislike her - This is called an 
opinion which I am currently clinging to as you are clinging to yours, just 
stop all the hate on someone who dislikes a stupid FICTIONAL brat who 
happens to accidentally kill the father to one of their favourite 
characters.
comments.author: franki saurus

comments.text:
Because she's a girl who sews instead of fights and is therefore HORRIBLE. 
Seriously, I've rarely seen any severe Sansa hate that isn't rooted in 
intense misogyny and/or lack of perspective.
comments.author: Wendy Weissman

comments.text:
+Wendy Weissman This 100%. Are we gonna call an *11 year old* girl a b-word 
for making a mistake??
comments.author: Syedaxox

comments.text:
+Wendy Weissman  I still think Sansa caused their deaths. And yes, its so 
much fun to blame little girls. Especially when they're FICTIONAL 
CHARACTERS.
comments.author: franki saurus

comments.text:
+franki saurus Ned killed Ned. He a) Told Cersei what he knew b) waited 
until the last minute to tell his children anything that was up, 
effectively told his daughter he was axing her future, then left her 
unsupervised, c) Did everything possible to leave himself and his children 
completely vulnerable, and d) Refused to keep his mouth shut and make 
decent partnerships in order to keep his family safe. He was a horrifyingly 
neglectful parent (who let his other daughter run amok in a city full of 
rapists unsupervised) and owed his older daughter an explanation, which he 
refused to give (despite the fact that he had been the one to sign her up 
for a betrothal to a family he believed to be murderous traitors without 
giving her any forewarning of that). Sansa was a little girl who wanted to 
go say good-bye to Cersei and Joffrey before she was forced to leave the 
capital, mostly because at that point (and yes, this is in the books) they 
were the only ones who showed her much or any consolation for what happened 
at the Trident. Like making sure she, an eleven year old highborn rich 
girl, had a guard to escort her back through the rapist filled city (yep. 
Hand's Tourney, Joffrey does this. Ned does not. He sends her outside the 
city with an old drunk nun and no guards. Joffrey has the Houndd escort her 
back, effectively showing more concern for Sansa's welfare than her own 
father).

So yeah, go ahead, blame the twelve year old for what happened and not the 
grown ass man who actually knew what was going on and was willing to sell 
his twelve year old to the Lannisters in order to make sure they didn't 
"doubt his loyalty." You go ahead and do that. It's so much more fun to 
blame little girls.
comments.author: Wendy Weissman

comments.text:
+anik558 I've tried finding the episode but it turns out the producers left 
that scene out as it was easier to portray Sansa as the disobedient, 
spoiled girl rather than the obedient spoiled kid that betrays her father 
for love. Plus the producers didn't want the fans to resent Sansa as much 
as everyone did when we all read the books
comments.author: franki saurus

comments.text:

Well, when there's only one correct answer, it can't be helped if most 
people come to that conclusion.

comments.author: anik558

comments.text:
+anik558 
in the book: 'She was the good girl, the obedient girl, but she had felt as 
wicked as Arya that morning, sneaking away from Septa Mordane, defying her 
lord father. She had never done anything so wilful before, and she would 
never have done it then if she hadn't loved Joffrey as much as she did. "He 
was going to take me back to Winterfell and marry me to some hedge knight, 
even though it was Joff I wanted. I told him, but he wouldn't listen." The 
King had been her last hope. The King could command Father to let her stay 
in King's Landing and marry Prince Joffrey, Sansa knew he could, but the 
King had always frightened her. He was loud and rough-voiced and  drunk  as 
often as not, and he would probably have just sent her back to Lord Eddard, 
if they ever let her see him. *So she went to the queen instead, and poured 
her heart out to her, and Cercei had listened and thanked her sweetly...* '
However if you want an extract from the series just ask and I will try and 
find it for ya.

comments.text:
+sykogrupycocanekrzy In the Westeros honor, glory, duty, "winning", they 
mean NOTHING. They're phantom concepts of the deluded. Surviving is what 
matters. That's why the Boltons are on top, and why I think they'll stay 
there. Have you read the books? Because Robb Stark won ever battle, Robert 
Baratheon conquered seven kingdoms. Both of them were too preoccupied with 
honor and glory to see the knives at their throats. Liking or disliking the 
Boltons for their cruelty isn't the point. They can outlive everyone else, 
rule the pile of corpses, they aren't going to slit their own throats 
because its would be immoral to sleep with a woman and not marry her.

and her Dragons, who

would be riderless, as neither Tyrion nor Victarion (Greyjoy) would be sent 
to Essos to eventually interact with Dany (T. isn't blamed for Joff's 
death, and as Balon doesn't get pushed into the sea, there is no need for a 
Iron Islands meeting). 

SPOILERS END !!!!!!!

Fun to think about it though, since Sansa even considers grabbing Joffrey 
and jumping off the bridge with him in that scene. ﻿

comments.text:
I'm beginning to think the only satisfactory fantasy story I'll get is if I 
write one myself. Honestly this seems to be no interesting books that I've 
found yet and I'm beginning to tire of the same old story with different 
characters with different names.... The last fantasy book I read was the 
Silmarillionand it was pretty good I guess....
comments.author: Thebbookgirrl101

comments.text:
+Thebbookgirrl101 It really does, most of it is cliched and unoriginal and 
I am just waiting for something truly game changing.
comments.author: Pancake Lord

comments.text:
I read that series and... The only thing I could remember about it was the 
great blue Dragon and that's it. I think there was an elf in there 
somewhere but the series all kind of blends together.... But yeah I don't 
know manyFantasy authors and lessWho writeabout dragons so I'm always on 
the hunt for a good book. Almost every author that I have tried reading 
that was suggested to me by friends are either boring or just okay.... I 
think the fantasy genre needs a little bit more originality....
comments.author: Thebbookgirrl101

comments.text:
+Thebbookgirrl101 The only other thing I can think of with dragons right 
now is Eragon. I have always thought The Vampyre was good (random book that 
popped into mind)
comments.author: Pancake Lord

comments.text:
I like mythology and some fantasy but right now I'm not really reading 
anything because for a long time I can't find anything to my liking.... I 
especially love bookswith dragons in them,I don't know why,and that is why 
a friend recommended a song of ice and fire. Unfortunately for me,I am 
highly critical and always point out the flaws and everything even stuff 
that I like.
comments.author: Thebbookgirrl101

comments.text:
+Thebbookgirrl101 Quick question, what books are you into? And now I 
understand that you meant Robert, thanks.
comments.author: Pancake Lord

comments.text:
I meant king Robert. He is a horrible king! If there's no morality in game 
of thrones how come some assassin didn't just kill him already? Also, The 
same thing goes for all the terrible people in these books. I don't know. 
Every one seems to love this book and I don't know what I'm missing. I was 
looking forward to something new and unique but all I found were some 
stereotypes and plot twists thrown in for good measure. I was disappointed 
and eventually had to stop reading halfway through the third book because 
someone told me that there would be even more different character point of 
use... I say find a good cast of characters that will support the reader 
through the story and stick with them that way it would make your story 
flow and have the same quality all the way through... That's not to say you 
can't kill a few off but consistency is always good in a book series But 
what do I know? I haven't made lots of money on my stories after all....
comments.author: Thebbookgirrl101

comments.text:
+Thebbookgirrl101 True, but most of the POVs are kinda neutral and Martin 
at least makes them more reasonable while other authors just make a lot of 
their characters so one dimensional. I am curious about who you meant when 
you said drunk king.
comments.author: Pancake Lord

comments.text:
True. The only good guys were the StarkFamily and what happened to them? 
Three are dead in therest are in hiding. Would I dislike most about 
Martin's series that I have read so far is that good is rarely rewarded and 
is most of the time punished. I'm not saying you have to be like Tolkienand 
have most of the good guys live but sometimes bad people get wits coming to 
them and that's one of the key things that are missing in this series. Of 
course,most people think that bad people when most of the time and most 
people like their fantasy to be somewhat realistic but honestly there's 
only so much realism I like in my books. I think that if you have a good 
charactergood and bad things should happen to that character just as if you 
have a bad character. Also, The series is highly praised for having its 
"well rounded characters." The way I see it,almost every fantasy author has 
one or two stereotypical characters.
The drunk king,
The girly girl,
The tomboy,
The overprotective mother,
The exiled princess, 
The evil prints.
These are all examples of stereotypes found in a song of ice and fire.
comments.author: Thebbookgirrl101

comments.text:
+Thebbookgirrl101 I don't think the 'goodguys' are necessarily retarded / 
stupid I think its because they adhere to a code of conduct or a moral code 
which the Lannisters  for example don't. Which in my opinion makes the good 
guys look bad because they're playing to rules which the others are not.
